No Man's Sky is an ambitious, decently fun game about exploring over 18 quintillion semi-unique very large prodcedurally generated planets and doing other fun stuff in space like stealing money, smuggling, fighting, building, farming, hunting, and the like.
It's a very wide and rather shallow game in that the gameplay loop gets a bit old if you do the same things (mine, craft, build, repeat) but there's actually a lot of cool misson-type content and the sheer scale of the game is genuinley awe-inspiring.
The developers (Hello Games) have more than repented of the game's rocky launch nearly a decade ago, and they give free and interesting updates all the time.
I don't know if you should buy this game for $60, but for $30 on sale it's a great investment.
Also, there's such cool events as encounters with a massive space worm in the void that I saw a month ago which is hyper-rare, exploring creepy abandoned spaceships, and unearthing the story's lore.
If you're into linear story games and get bored in a sandboxy vibe. this probably is not for you, but it's a very fun, original vibe that feels kinda like "Minecraft in Space with Better Graphics".
Thanks for reading this, hopefully you are better informed on your purchase!

After spending hundreds of hours roaming the stars on console and now diving back in on PC, it's hard not to appreciate just how far No Man’s Sky has come. What started as an ambitious, if uneven, or some might say "Abomination" (I'm not kidding), spacefaring experiment has steadily evolved into one of the most rewarding and generosity-driven games out there. 

Now, returning to it feels a bit like coming home to a universe that’s grown up in all the right ways. and the credit goes straight to the team at Hello Games. Few developers commit to a vision as passionately as they have. Update after update—all free, mind you—they’ve expanded this universe with new mechanics, new modes, new stories, and new ways to play. Base building, living ships, deep-sea exploration, space expeditions, VR support… the list is long enough to feel like several new games stacked inside one. It’s rare to see a studio not only stick to its promise but overshoot it by a galaxy and a half.

After all this years, the game still nails that feeling of stepping onto an untouched planet, hearing the low hum of alien winds, and thinking "Alright, what’s out there this time?"

Now, the ecosystems feel richer, the colors more vibrant, and the handcrafted chaos of procedural generation somehow more believable than ever. Well, sometimes it throws out the odd weird planet that looks like someone dropped watercolor paint on a golf ball. But those quirks are easy to forgive when the universe is this massive, this welcoming, and this lovingly supported. Whether you're mining resources, uncovering ancient mysteries, or simply taking your starship for a joyride through a nebula, the game radiates a quiet magic.

In the end, No Man’s Sky is more than a comeback story—it’s a long-term commitment to players, a testament to how a game can grow when its developers believe in it wholeheartedly. And after spending so many hours across two platforms, I can confidently say this: there’s never been a better time to step into the stars.

The game's music fits perfectly into the lonely and intense atmosphere of the game.

This game is an experience and, to me, it's one of the greatest games ever made.

I played No Man's Sky at launch, a rare day-one purchase for me, because it felt like there was something a little bit different about it.  I very much enjoyed it, pockling around a few planets, talking to the different aliens, and exploring, quite aimlessly, what the game had to offer.  It was very quickly apparent that there wasn't an awful lot of game here.  It was exploration for the sake of moving on to the next planet.  Which honestly, I was fine with, even if many felt they had been misled by the developer's promises.  But I also felt done after about 10 hours.  It felt like I had seen everything I wanted to.

Nine years later I picked the game up again, and there was a lot more structure and drive.  There wa always something to do, in a way that there just wasn't before.  I've played about 80 hours since, and enjoyed it greatly.  The story was interesting, contemplative, and fit the game play loop very well.  With the content has come more shaving off of the edges, the content is smoother and more streamlined.  I've seen many more planets than my first playthrough...but I haven't felt that same sense of wonder from pure exploration.  For many this trade off will be more than worth it, even if it gives me a lingering sense of what might have been, had the worlds been a little more like the covers of the old sci-fi novels, rather than the same building and three species (which is explained in the story, but still glaring in a near infinite universe).

All in all, a very enjoyable experience.  The developers should be commended for their dedication to the game and releasing so many updates since launch.

It started as a void. A promise whispered into the static that broke upon arrival. But what followed is perhaps the greatest comeback story in the history of this medium. Where others would have abandoned the ship or sold the wreckage for parts, Sean Murray and Hello Games went silent. Not to hide, but to work. For years, they have been delivering massive, transformative expansions - all free of charge. In an era of aggressive monetization and unfinished "live services," this level of integrity feels almost alien. It is a labor of love that borders on obsession. They didn’t just fix the game; they expanded the definition of what it could be.

Inside the simulation, the experience evokes a specific kind of loneliness - not the scary kind, but the clear, cold isolation of a deep diver. You are a speck of dust in a procedural engine, chasing signals across an infinite canvas. Visually, it oscillates between pulp sci-fi covers of the 70s and a modern screen-saver dream. It is beautiful, vast, and occasionally, oppressively empty.

The gameplay loop is hypnotic: mine, build, fly, repeat. It scratches the itch for order in chaos. However, the mask of the procedural generation eventually slips. After the hundredth [well, it depends] planet, you start seeing the patterns in the matrix, and the wonder fades into a comfortable routine. It is not a perfect universe; the combat often feels weightless, and the infinite breadth sometimes lacks infinite depth. But as a testament to developer loyalty and a sandbox for the mind, it is unparalleled.

Recommended for those who respect the craft of world-building and find peace in the hum of a hyperdrive.

No Man’s Sky is a remarkable game, one I’d been looking forward to since childhood. I watched it with wide eyed excitement, but unfortunately, at launch it wasn’t anywhere close to the dream we were promised. It felt like the whole vision collapsed under its own ambition. And yet despite the reviews, despite the backlash, despite everyone calling it dead Hello Games didn’t give up. That’s something you almost never see in this industry. They could’ve walked away, but instead they rebuilt the game piece by piece. Today, No Man’s Sky is almost unrecognizable. Worlds actually feel alive now, with ecosystems that breathe and move. The game gets fair, meaningful updates all the time. Everything looks polished, vibrant, and full of detail. They keep improving things, fixing old systems, reworking mechanics, and constantly adding new content things nobody even expected, and a lot more on top of that. This kind of dedication is extremely rare. It’s honestly one of the most impressive redemption arcs gaming has ever seen. So yeah personally, today I can absolutely recommend No Man’s Sky without hesitation.

Brilliant in many ways, and the devs' dedication to continuing to provide updates is commendable. However, I wish they applied that same degree of dedication to polishing what they already put out, even if that doesn't result in immediate revenue spikes. This comes in two categories:

1. Content itself. Upon discovering a new space station, of a completely different shape from the first space station I had encountered (COOL!), nothing killed my excitement faster than flying inside and finding a layout IDENTICAL to that of the first station, right down to the locations of crates that you can sometimes loot for a little bit of money. The next space station? The same. Derelict encounters in space? More copy-pasta. I believe this illustrates procedural generation's biggest intrinsic weakness, but it also represents a failure of the dev team to respond accordingly to that weakness by hand-crafting more content. Procedural generation is a tool to enhance the application of creativity to content creation, not a replacement for it. It should be used accordingly.

2. Much of the UI is unintuitive or outright "weird." Having to learn to hold down the mouse button and wait when changing options so that the change would activate before saving (a console/gamepad concession, perhaps, but still weird) was only the beginning.  I encounter various bugs somewhat regularly. Many small details demonstrate an obvious lack of polish. Some mechanics have been broken or rendered obsolete by game updates but not adjusted accordingly. Tutorials or other forms of onboarding are not robust and sometimes out of date. I could go on, but the short of it is that I spent FAR too much of my NMS-playing time with the game minimized and me searching online forums for answers to questions that should have been provided by the game itself.

I played for about 20 hours, and I will say that I enjoyed those hours a great deal, but after taking a month-long break from the game for travel and coming back to its UI warts and overall repetitiveness, I found myself not wanting to play anymore. Perhaps in another five years or so I will give it another go from the beginning, with a brand-new character, if it looks like some of the above issues have been addressed. (6/10)

There's an overwhelming amount of stuff to do, objectives to complete and places to go, but none of it is truly engaging. So much time is spent in menus, managing currencies. The concept of ultimate freedom in a fully-realized galaxy is appealing, but most of the gameplay revolves around trudging slowly from one map marker to the next. Traversal is slow and boring. It's easy to get stuck somewhere in the middle of random nowhere with no way to refuel or teleport.

There is no physicality to anything around the player, making everything feel flat and hollow. Combat oscillates between an insurmountable hindrance to blasting away innocent Spore-style creatures. Its procedurally-generated environments feel samey almost immediately, as the creatures, terrain and constructs all just swap out limbs, color palettes and markings. Nothing is truly imposing, unique or memorable. The nonsense words accompanying new discoveries are a reliable source of hilarious double-entendres in other languages (a planet called "Beans", a plant named "Itch" or a mineral called "Vomiting").

Crafting is streamlined fun initially, but gets overly complicated and finicky quickly. Resource and inventory management are a chore, there are too many disparate things, reagents, slots, upgrades and containers. The sense of exploration and discovery of unknown worlds is hampered by existing structures, settlers and generically-themed minimap markers with no discernable coherency. A new planet is littered with random artefacts, buildings, and constructed points of interest, exemplifying the tropes of open-world checklist-led blandness.

There is no sense of place and mystery, it's all just colorful, haphazard nonsense. The story is a convoluted mess of childish Space Adventure tropes, complete with Star Trek aliens (people wearing spacesuits and rubber masks). The tone is all over the place - a stranded astronaut exploring enigmatic anomalies one moment to rainbow fleets of ships and friendly vendors the next.

I have given this a lot of thought and I think it's finally time to give this my honest review, but after really REALLY wanting to like this game, I don't think I can recommend it.

Now let me be clear, there are some REALLY amazing parts to this game that I love. For one, the community (in my experience) is extremely positive, generous (go AFK in the anomaly while you eat lunch to see what I mean), and helpful. Easily one of the best communities I've experienced in gaming. The fact that this game is almost 10 years old and still dropping massive free updates is incredible and a testament to the developer's commitment to their community. The worlds (and space) are expansive and beautiful with incredible sense of scale. There are tons of materials to craft with and endless ways to construct a base. Lots of cool ships, tons of cosmetics, etc etc. The experience of discovery early on the game is compelling, too.

Unfortunately for me, it's the cons that drive me away. I bought this game with a friend to play together, as the game claims to be a multi-player co-op. It is not a multi-player co-op. It is a multi-player play-at-the-same-time-but-not-together. Above any other complaint that I might have, this really killed it for me. When you are playing with a friend, you can see each other, but you are playing two different games simultaneously. For instance, they will see an animal you don't see on your screen, they will occasionally have different weather than what you're currently experiencing even though you're standing next to each other, they will be fighting something that to you doesn't even exist or talking to an NPC who is not there to you, or mining resources you can't see. In my opinion, in their quest to make it so others could not affect your personal game, they ruined what could have made this the best multi-player game ever made. After one attempt at trying to play together, we decided instead to play solo, which I did for about two or three weeks straight, and where the rest of my issues come into play.

Aside from disappointing multi-player, this game is one of the buggiest games I've ever played to the point where it impacts the fun of the game. One example is I was fighting a sentinel capital ship in space, but whenever I got close enough to get under the shields to make an attack run, the ship would just blink out of existence. However, it was still there, because it was still attacking me. It would then randomly blink back into existence, and I was stuck somehow in the engine of the ship, taking constant damage, being unable to move very much as though I were stuck in the model of the ship. This happened multiple times with multiple sentinel capital ship encounters to the point where I stopped taking these fights altogether because they were so frustrating. I've clipped out of my freighter, I've been randomly launched out of my corvette into deep space, teleporting to a base with a corvette as your main ship places the corvette inside your base somehow making it impossible to move and sometimes forcing you to restart the game. These are a few of the many bugs I encountered, but they're the most frustrating ones. To HG's credit, they are active in addressing bugs, as they release updates fairly frequently, but some of these game breakers should just not exist in a game that's been out this long.

Finally, I think the part that finally made me give up was the monotony. After you've done the same quest or seen the same building or talked to the same NPC enough times, the game becomes very... samey. When I was first beginning, I built a base on every new planet I landed on because holy crap a new planet! But after a while, visiting a new star system I found myself not even compelled to visit any planet at all, let alone establish a base. What was the point? Any resource I needed I could already get. There's no reason to really establish a base anywhere specific aside from mining. There is a wide variety of fauna that varies per planet, but after a while you realize every animal is just a compilation of a few parts and body models that are slapped together and scaled and given a random name, sometimes looking exactly like others on other planets. It kind of kills the immersion when every cave you go into has exactly the same minerals, or every ocean you go into has exactly the same flora. The monotony of opening up the same boxes over and over, going through the excruciatingly painful NPC talking loop, having every archaeological site be exactly the same as the previous one, every building of its type is exactly the same, every sentinel fight is predictably the same, spending vast time and resources on settlements for them to benefit you extremely little, having meaningless NPCs and NPC interactions, having squadrons that do literally nothing but maybe draw aggro in a fight... the list goes on. Additionally, you have a huge planet to explore, but there's nothing really to see once you've landed and explored your general area. Every planet surface is a singular biome (plus ocean and cave), so once you've seen one part of it, you've seen the whole planet. Sure there are points of interest, sure there are loot boxes and hidden treasures everywhere, but there's no real reason to explore the rest of the planet. The minerals, flora, and fauna, which can range from 0 to maybe 20 different instances of each, do not change as you move around the planet, which is catastrophically immersion breaking given how rich in biodiversity one might imagine a planet capable of hosting life to be. It's unfathomable to me how you can create a space game about discovering new planets and have no sense of poles, tropics, different mineral/flora/fauna on different continents or in different parts of the planet. Imagine if you could actually land on a single planet and spend hours discovering mineral/flora/fauna and know that you barely scratched the surface of what is available because you haven't even been north or south or to the opposite side.

I wanted so much to love this game, I really really did, and I appreciate the effort put into making it so vast, but the tradeoff they made for breadth vs depth I don't think clicks for me. As a software developer by trade, I understand the limitations developers face making something so huge at scale and trying to keep it performant and interesting. But unfortunately I don't think they've succeeded outside of the initial maybe 30-50 hours, and they certainly dropped the ball with multi-player which is a huge disappointment. I would say that if they completely reworked how multiplayer works, (and maybe addressed some of the glaring bugs and tightened up some of the monotony, and maybe give some variety to planets), I would love to give this game another shot. To sum it up, you can buy No Man's Sky if you want a chill, relaxing experience about exploration, but if you have at least some care about gameplay depth, steer clear.
